title: I am going to be
categories: Discussion

imagelink: []

---

I am going to be running a table at Free RPG day and will be running DW. I want each game to only run about an hour or so.<br /><br />What quick start mission, module, or one shot do you suggest I bring?
<div id='comment z13hhxoasyihv5dxu04cftxpikirjhdp5mw0k'>
  <h4><img src='{{site.baseurl}}//images/avatars/101824580455031797035_photo.jpg'> Brian Holland</h4>
      <p><cite>2017-05-18 17:01:19 (edited: 2017-05-18 17:01:19)</cite></p>
        <p>One hour is tough unless you bring pre-generated characters, which I don&#39;t like for DW. Character Creation can last up to an hour sometimes when we&#39;re starting a new game.<br /><br />But, with pre-gens, I think any of the Sword Breaker zines by <span class="proflinkWrapper"><span class="proflinkPrefix">+</span><a class="proflink" href="https://plus.google.com/117938653641565340771" oid="117938653641565340771">Logan Howard</a></span> could work in an hour, and also any of the Dungeon Starters by <span class="proflinkWrapper"><span class="proflinkPrefix">+</span><a class="proflink" href="https://plus.google.com/118088719859349999400" oid="118088719859349999400">Mark Tygart</a></span>.<br /><br />I just really don&#39;t like the idea of Pre-gens for DW lol</p>
</div>
        

<div id='comment z13hhxoasyihv5dxu04cftxpikirjhdp5mw0k'>
  <h4><img src='{{site.baseurl}}//images/avatars/114565208078196505939_photo.jpg'> Charles Gatz</h4>
      <p><cite>2017-05-18 17:41:49 (edited: 2017-05-18 17:41:49)</cite></p>
        <p>1) what is this Free RPG day you speak of?<br />2) I agree w/ Brian, I made a post about my own issues w/ time/player constraints: <a href="https://plus.google.com/+CharlesGatz/posts/2fVFqUp6WBR" class="ot-anchor">https://plus.google.com/+CharlesGatz/posts/2fVFqUp6WBR</a> <br /><br />3) In the interest of giving a &quot;yes, but&quot; answer, I think maybe a better way to run a tight 1-hour one-shot is to just throw away anything non-essential (basically everything but the core 2d6 requirement, HP, armor), like I did one night at a bar (which still went out to 2 hours, but I could&#39;ve skipped an encounter.).<br /><br />a) Have the players pick a class or role, but don&#39;t get bogged down by reading over all the class moves. If they&#39;re not familiar w/ D&amp;D, have them just come up with something, a genie, a sentient tree, a mutant, whatever, and decide on one active move, and maybe a passive. If they think their character should be able to do something as it comes up, use the &quot;yes, but...&quot; approach, and roll with it. I had a character pick a caster type, and she came up with a move similar to a portal gun right before the boss fight.<br /><br />b) speaking of &quot;boss fight&quot;, I&#39;d probably aim for just 2 encounters, the first relatively straightforward to get their feet wet (i.e., hack and slash, defy danger, and/or volley come up), and then straight to the Big Bad... Ask the questions to get them to why they&#39;re in this fight (e.g., the intro to Deadpool), so that you can get straight through the &#39;tutorial&#39; with enough time to segue into the boss fight -- to the players, it should really just feel like one extended fight.<br /><br />c) Assign modifiers, not stats: plus 2, a few plus ones, two zeroes, and a minus one.<br /><br />d) Make gear selection as streamlined as possible: everyone can start with adventuring gear and rations. Healing potion/ antitoxin/ armor if it makes sense for that class, but let them at least pick their weapon(s), without fussing too much over tags (&quot;we&#39;ll get to that if it comes up, but for instance, 1 piercing means it pierces one point of armor, precise means you can use your DEX instead of STR, that kind of thing&quot;).<br /><br />e) probably just personal opinion, but forget about making camp and UaPJ... basically any of the advanced moves. Also, they&#39;re unlikely to feel that XP is worth anything, so maybe use it another way -- spend an XP to re-roll (or give another player a re-roll)?<br /><br />I could probably come up with some more &#39;strip it down&#39; tips, but I still need to grab lunch :)</p>
</div>
        

<div id='comment z13hhxoasyihv5dxu04cftxpikirjhdp5mw0k'>
  <h4><img src='{{site.baseurl}}//images/avatars/110301622772119888974_photo.jpg'> Andrew Huffaker</h4>
      <p><cite>2017-05-18 19:14:01 (edited: 2017-05-18 19:14:01)</cite></p>
        <p><a href="http://www.freerpgday.com/" data-embed="CNECCNACCM8CCAASGmh0dHA6Ly93d3cuZnJlZXJwZ2RheS5jb20vOj8I1L_s58ErEhpodHRwOi8vd3d3LmZyZWVycGdkYXkuY29tLxoaaHR0cDovL3d3dy5mcmVlcnBnZGF5LmNvbS_" data-attachment-render-hint="1" class="ot-anchor">http://www.freerpgday.com/</a><br /></p>
</div>
        

<div id='comment z13hhxoasyihv5dxu04cftxpikirjhdp5mw0k'>
  <h4><img src='{{site.baseurl}}//images/avatars/107323876295285638890_photo.jpg'> Benjamin Kramer (Photostyle)</h4>
      <p><cite>2017-05-18 19:14:46 (edited: 2017-05-18 19:14:46)</cite></p>
        <p><span class="proflinkWrapper"><span class="proflinkPrefix">+</span><a class="proflink" href="https://plus.google.com/114565208078196505939" oid="114565208078196505939">Charles Gatz</a></span> Free RPG Day is a &#39;national&#39; &#39;get-people-into-the-hobby&#39; event where local game stores host RPG games with varying systems. Publishers provide small quick-start rule sets or samples, and store staff or other volunteers run convention-style sessions. (usually ~4 hours.) It&#39;s a great chance to try out a new system and meet other local gamers, while hopefully giving your host store some always-welcome business.</p>
</div>
        

<div id='comment z13hhxoasyihv5dxu04cftxpikirjhdp5mw0k'>
  <h4><img src='{{site.baseurl}}//images/avatars/110301622772119888974_photo.jpg'> Andrew Huffaker</h4>
      <p><cite>2017-05-18 19:18:46 (edited: 2017-05-18 19:18:46)</cite></p>
        <p>I work at a school and I have ran multiple one hour sessions with players using stripped down characters. Like <span class="proflinkWrapper"><span class="proflinkPrefix">+</span><a class="proflink" href="https://plus.google.com/114565208078196505939" oid="114565208078196505939">Charles Gatz</a></span> stated, so I think that&#39;s good advice. I don&#39;t ever really care about gear, gold, loot, etc. outside of maybe 1 or 2 sought after weapons. I just make sure that there is pressure and action. I have ran hour sessions for Language Arts Special Education classes of about 8 or so kids at a time and I just have to try to be really REALLY narrative focused and not care about things like gold or healing. I support that by not letting anyone a second to rest between scenes. In media res and no travel times. Just scene after scene. <br /><br />What I&#39;m going to be running at RPG day is just going to be enough to showcase the mechanics and how it is different from DND, Path, etc. <br /><br />Does anyone have a quick one shot that they think really plays into the feeling or is quintessential to the mechanics/genre?</p>
</div>
        

<div id='comment z13hhxoasyihv5dxu04cftxpikirjhdp5mw0k'>
  <h4><img src='{{site.baseurl}}//images/avatars/118088719859349999400_photo.jpg'> Mark Tygart</h4>
      <p><cite>2017-05-18 21:19:13 (edited: 2017-05-18 21:19:13)</cite></p>
        <p><a href="https://drive.google.com/file/d/0B7cav44145d9U0w5YlBlbFZUeW8/view?usp=sharing" data-embed="CNECCNACCM8CCAASTWh0dHBzOi8vZHJpdmUuZ29vZ2xlLmNvbS9maWxlL2QvMEI3Y2F2NDQxNDVkOVUwdzVZbEJsYkZaVWVXOC92aWV3P3VzcD1zaGFyaW5nOqUBCOa3tevBKxJNaHR0cHM6Ly9kcml2ZS5nb29nbGUuY29tL2ZpbGUvZC8wQjdjYXY0NDE0NWQ5VTB3NVlsQmxiRlpVZVc4L3ZpZXc_dXNwPXNoYXJpbmcaTWh0dHBzOi8vZHJpdmUuZ29vZ2xlLmNvbS9maWxlL2QvMEI3Y2F2NDQxNDVkOVUwdzVZbEJsYkZaVWVXOC92aWV3P3VzcD1zaGFyaW5n0uSWmQHZCQpNaHR0cHM6Ly9kcml2ZS5nb29nbGUuY29tL2ZpbGUvZC8wQjdjYXY0NDE0NWQ5VTB3NVlsQmxiRlpVZVc4L3ZpZXc_" data-attachment-render-hint="1" class="ot-anchor">https://drive.google.com/file/d/0B7cav44145d9U0w5YlBlbFZUeW8/view?usp=sharing</a> old, but a popular classic</p>

<div id='comment z13hhxoasyihv5dxu04cftxpikirjhdp5mw0k'>

You are the master!</p>

<div id='comment z13hhxoasyihv5dxu04cftxpikirjhdp5mw0k'>
  <h4><img src='{{site.baseurl}}//images/avatars/110301622772119888974_photo.jpg'> Andrew Huffaker</h4>
      <p><cite>2017-05-18 22:15:32 (edited: 2017-05-18 22:15:32)</cite></p>
        <p><span class="proflinkWrapper"><span class="proflinkPrefix">+</span><a class="proflink" href="https://plus.google.com/118088719859349999400" oid="118088719859349999400">Mark Tygart</a></span> Why were you so modest as to not suggest your own?</p>
</div>
        

<div id='comment z13hhxoasyihv5dxu04cftxpikirjhdp5mw0k'>
  <h4><img src='{{site.baseurl}}//images/avatars/109791996665503926061_photo.jpg'> Robert Rendell</h4>
      <p><cite>2017-05-18 22:46:53 (edited: 2017-05-18 22:50:28)</cite></p>
        <p>As an alternative to pre-gens, have you seen Peter J&#39;s simplified playbooks?  (G+ isn&#39;t letting me + his name alas)<br /><br /><a href="https://drive.google.com/file/d/0BwbHes6iNuGrbVZ2ZDgyMUhCR1U/view" data-embed="-hFBaHR0cHM6Ly9kcml2ZS5nb29nbGUuY29tL2ZpbGUvZC8wQndiSGVzNmlOdUdyYlZaMlpEZ3lNVWhDUjFVL3ZpZXc" data-attachment-render-hint="1" class="ot-anchor">drive.google.com - Dungeon World Simple Playbooks.pdf - Google Drive</a><br /><br />They do as <span class="proflinkWrapper"><span class="proflinkPrefix">+</span><a class="proflink" href="https://plus.google.com/114565208078196505939" oid="114565208078196505939">Charles Gatz</a></span> suggests and leave out stat numbers - the player&#39;s chosen Background dictates their base modifiers, and then they get to add +1 to one and -1 to another.<br /><br />The playbooks also simplify the base moves to just a few simple choices (e.g. the Druid&#39;s &quot;Shapeshifter&quot; move lists specific animals along with their moves, the Wizard&#39;s &quot;Cast a Spell&quot; move lists the magical effects directly in the move rather than having a spell list, the Fighter&#39;s Signature Weapon is chosen from a list etc.)<br /><br />Instead of listing the advanced moves on the back, they give the Basic Moves and a quick &quot;how to play&quot; guide.<br /></p>
</div>
        

<div id='comment z13hhxoasyihv5dxu04cftxpikirjhdp5mw0k'>
  <h4><img src='{{site.baseurl}}//images/avatars/118088719859349999400_photo.jpg'> Mark Tygart</h4>

<div id='comment z13hhxoasyihv5dxu04cftxpikirjhdp5mw0k'>
  <h4><img src='{{site.baseurl}}//images/avatars/118088719859349999400_photo.jpg'> Mark Tygart</h4>
      <p><cite>2017-05-18 23:09:29 (edited: 2017-05-18 23:09:29)</cite></p>
        <p><span class="proflinkWrapper"><span class="proflinkPrefix">+</span><a class="proflink" href="https://plus.google.com/110301622772119888974" oid="110301622772119888974">Andrew Huffaker</a></span> And yes I&#39;m a poor judge of my own work...but always happy if it helps others!</p>
</div>
        

<div id='comment z13hhxoasyihv5dxu04cftxpikirjhdp5mw0k'>
  <h4><img src='{{site.baseurl}}//images/avatars/114565208078196505939_photo.jpg'> Charles Gatz</h4>
      <p><cite>2017-05-18 23:44:53 (edited: 2017-05-18 23:44:53)</cite></p>
        <p>I was thinking of recommending this one (and thought against it [note]), and while following the comments, thought, &quot;that name looks familiar...&quot; so I&#39;ll call <span class="proflinkWrapper"><span class="proflinkPrefix">+</span><a class="proflink" href="https://plus.google.com/118088719859349999400" oid="118088719859349999400">Mark Tygart</a></span> out for a &quot;mini-dungeon&quot; I ran for a group of 3 first-time players (but had all at least played something similar once or twice before) plus my (gamer) gf. The Tombs of Atuan: <br /> <a href="https://drive.google.com/file/d/0B7cav44145d9a3U2NjFWR0ptWjg/view" class="ot-anchor">https://drive.google.com/file/d/0B7cav44145d9a3U2NjFWR0ptWjg/view</a>  ... it went well, despite them not ever encountering the Painted Room or Room of Chains -- they did, however, pick up on the &quot;someone&quot; added to the Labyrinth move, and rescue a person from one of the characters&#39; backgrounds (all them, very DW,  much fun). I felt it showcased the Labyrinth move as a way to abstract and offload the traditional dungeon crawl, using the most basic form of being dropped  medias res: imprisonment. <br /><br />[note] However, I can&#39;t recommend the Labyrinth move for a 1-hour session, as there&#39;s simply too much unpredictability in the dice, and works best (imo) with a sort of &quot;5 room&quot; design, as the Tombs of Atuan does. You&#39;re looking for a two, three <b>at the most</b> &quot;room&quot; adventure &quot;micro&quot; dungeon, if you will -- or something entirely different and more PbtA-ish.<br /><br />As to starting with imprisonment, I first heard of DW from this guy: <a href="https://youtu.be/AIFxPXlTzlQ" class="ot-anchor">https://youtu.be/AIFxPXlTzlQ</a> when I was considering running D&amp;D games, but wanted to see what else is out there (I&#39;m also excited to get into The Strange...). That particular video is a bit long (there are antics to skip or enjoy), but the first encounter is a prison, a popular choice for a reason. I wouldn&#39;t follow things to the letter, but there&#39;s a lot of good advice there. Note that his &quot;room DCs&quot; are just some kind of threat you can push DD rolls with.</p>
</div>
        

<div id='comment z13hhxoasyihv5dxu04cftxpikirjhdp5mw0k'>
  <h4><img src='{{site.baseurl}}//images/avatars/118088719859349999400_photo.jpg'> Mark Tygart</h4>
      <p><cite>2017-05-18 23:52:36 (edited: 2017-05-18 23:52:36)</cite></p>
        <p><span class="proflinkWrapper"><span class="proflinkPrefix">+</span><a class="proflink" href="https://plus.google.com/114565208078196505939" oid="114565208078196505939">Charles Gatz</a></span> Thanks for the feedback/war stories; always very useful!</p>
</div>
